messageBody:
RE: [junit] cannot run testing with UI TestRunner?

Did you not see this? I noticed it was missing from your reply:
--
I even tried rebuilding my app from a full set of source files (including
dom source).

The problem with the -noloading is that one can't rerun individual test
cases after a rebuild :-(

Fergus
--
The classloader issue comes up not just with the org.w3c object. I tripped across the -noloading botch myself, and wasted a good couple of hours trying to diagnose my problems with it.

This kind of thing provides great material to use to trip up folks during technical interviews, but is hardly conducive to the deliverance of bullet-proof software when your client is paying you by the hour.

Finally, I'd point out that someone shows up in this Yahoo.group having tripped over this JUnit classloader with a frequency of about 1 per week. Given that, do you really think my criticism is unwarranted?

    -----Original Message-----
    From:   Dinwiddie, George [SMTP:George.Dinwiddie@...]
    Sent:   Tuesday, March 27, 2001 8:30 AM
    To:     'junit@yahoogroups.com'
    Subject:        RE: [junit] cannot run testing with UI TestRunner?

    Chuck,
     
    I think your criticism is unwarranted.  First of all, I find JUnit to be a wonderful help and I'm very glad to have it.  Second, the JUnit classloader DOES work.  I don't know what's going on within org.w3c.dom.Document, but in general, when the -noloading switch solves the problem it indicates that some part of the software is using a different class loader and that results in an object mismatch.  The response to this is to disable JUnit's reloading class loader and use the default one (which will not reload changed classes) that the software under test is expecting.  Is this a bad design decision?  Do you have a better solution to this problem?

     
     - George

      -----Original Message-----
      From: Herrick, Chuck [mailto:chuck.herrick@...]
      Sent: Tuesday, March 27, 2001 8:37 AM
      To: 'junit@yahoogroups.com'
      Subject: RE: [junit] cannot run testing with UI TestRunner?

      Take a look at the security machinations that Java demands the classloader undergo on behalf of the virtual machine.

      I would say that if JUnit can't complete some very fundamental piece of its business because the authors made bad design decisions regarding the classloader, you'd need to get someone to go back and refactor JUnit.

      Perhaps someone should have tested JUnit with some test software before rolling it out.
